answers: antiknock agents [accept equivalents such as “additives that reduce engine knocking”]
parts: Name this compound in which two equivalents of η5 (“eta-5”) cyclopentadienyl are coordinated to iron. It was the first sandwich compound discovered.

MMT and ferrocene can be used as one of these compounds which prevent fuel exploding outside the envelope of the combustion front. Thomas Midgley created one of these agents which was phased out due to toxicity.

Damage due to engine knock can also be reduced by using gasoline with a high rating named for this compound. This compound and its isomers are the main component of gasoline, and its chemical formula is C8H18.

answers: Art Nouveau [do not accept or prompt on “Art Deco”]
parts: Name this family, two members of which collaborated to design such International Style buildings as the Kleinhans Music Hall in Buffalo, New York and the Christ Church Lutheran in Minneapolis.

The younger Saarinen, Eero, went on to design part of one of these places in New York which later became a hotel. He also designed the main terminal for one of them named Dulles in the Washington, D.C. area.

The elder Saarinen, Eliel, initially produced several buildings in this architectural style before it was replaced in popularity by Art Deco. Victor Horta’s Hotel Tassel in this style was influenced by the natural curves of vines.

answers: income [or household income or total national income]
GNP [or Gross National Product, or GNI, or Gross National Income; do not accept or prompt on “modified gross national income” or “GNI*”]
parts: Name this quantity, which is defined as the total of wages, rents, interest, and profits when calculating national GDP. In progression taxation schemes, households with a higher value for this quantity paying more in taxes.

If a worker from Mexico makes widgets for their Texas-based company, their production does not count towards Mexican GDP. Their work does, however, count towards Mexico’s value for this quantity which, unlike GDP, incorporates foreign investments by a country’s citizens.
If a country has net positive foreign investment, then by definition its value for this quantity must be higher than if it had negative net foreign investment.

answers: Armenia AND Azerbaijan [accept Republic of Armenia or Hayastani Hanrapetut'yun for “Armenia”; accept
parts: Name these two countries which recently warred over the regions of Nagorno-Karabakh (“NAH-gor-noh KAH-rah-bahk”) and Nakhchivan (“NAKH-chih-van”), disputed since they gained independence from the USSR.
Both countries and disputed regions are very mountainous, as this mountain system between the Caspian Sea and Black Sea covers much of their land.

A special OSCE group named for and held in this European capital city has mediated the Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict since 1992. The hills named for this city are the source of the Neman river of Napoleonic fame.

answers: John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough [or John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough]
landscape gardens [accept garden hermits or Hanging Gardens]
parts: Name this country house in Oxfordshire named after a 1704 battle in Bavaria. It was designed in the English Baroque style by Sir John Vanbrugh and was partially funded by Queen Anne.
Blenheim Palace was built by this English general to commemorate his victory at the Battle of Blenheim during the War of Spanish Succession.

One of these places in Blenheim Palace was designed by Capability Brown. English aristocrats in the 18th century sometimes hired hermits to live in these places, a “Hanging” variety of which was built in Babylon.

Name this German philosopher who described a concept as “man’s emergence from his self immaturity”. In this thinker’s most famous work, he described the perceptual concepts of “schemata” and “noumena.”
This magnus opus of Kant distinguishes the noumenon, or “thing in itself” and the phenomenon. The statement “7+5 = 12” is said to be an a priori truth in this work.
A chapter of Critique of Pure Reason named for this subject describes space and time as a priori intuitions. In Kant’s Critique of Judgement, he describes four reflective judgements of this subject.

answers: a car race [accept equivalents, accept “After the Race”]
parts: Name this collection. This collection includes the story “A Little Cloud”, as well as another story that ends with Gabriel Conroy noticing snow falling outside a window.
Dubliners is by this Irish author of A Portrait of the Artist of a Young Man and Ulysses.

In one story in Dubliners, Jimmy Doyle participates in one of these events with his friend Charles Segouin. That story titled for one of these events ends with the pianist Villona yelling “Daybreak, gentlemen!”

answers: quark-gluon plasma [or QGP; prompt on plasma; prompt on quark matter or QCD matter]
tidal forces [accept tides or tidal bulges]
parts: “Nuclear pasta” is a theoretical type of matter that is postulated to exist in the crust of neutron stars and surround this material, thought to be at the star’s core. In this material, the two main components of hadrons are separated from one another.
The Gnocchi (“NYOH-kee”) phase of ultradense nuclear pasta may be formed after one of these powerful and luminous stellar explosions which result from the collapse of a star’s core.

“Spaghettification” occurs when extreme examples of these forces near black holes stretch matter into extremely thin, long rods. In general, these forces “squish” orbiting objects to form namesake “bulges.”
Give the English language name for a set of laws issued in the 1870s by Adalbert Falk which made the state responsible for the training of clergy.
The latter set of May Laws were part of this policy with a German name, implemented in the 1870s, which sought to reduce Catholic influence in the recently-consolidated Germany.
The Kulturkampf was initiated by this German Chancellor who gave the “Blood and Iron” speech.

answers: South Korea [or Daehan Minguk; or Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea]
parts: Name this 2007 novel which follows Yeong-Hye’s (“yung-hyeh’z”) mental decline after she has nightmares about animals being slaughtered.
The author of The Vegetarian, Han Kang, is from this country, whose students read the war diary of national hero Yi Sun-Sin (“ee soon-sheen”) in their literature classes.

The Korean woman Miu runs away with the writer Sumire (“soo-mee-ray”) in this author’s Sputnik Sweetheart. In another of this author’s novels, the alter ego Crow learns about a man who makes flutes out of the souls of cats.

answers: storms [accept snow storms or thunderstorms or tempests]
parts: Name this artist who depicted a Native American holding a feathered spear while hunting on horseback in the painting The Last of the Buffalo.
Albert Bierstadt was a German-born member of this American school of painting and was known for his large, sweeping landscapes. Its other members include Thomas Cole and Asher Durand.

A Native American camp appears beneath Lander’s Peak in Bierstadt’s painting of one of these events “in the Rocky Mountains.” J. M. W. Turner’s painting of Hannibal crossing the Alps is titled for one of these events.

answers: ferromagnetism [accept word forms; prompt on magnetism; do not accept or prompt on “paramagnetism”]
exchange interaction [accept exchange energy or exchange force or exchange mechanism; accept exchange integral]
Pauli exclusion principle [prompt on exclusion principle]
parts: Name this property that can be modeled by a lattice of adjacent spins in the Ising model.

This phenomenon’s namesake energy is plotted on the y-axis of the Bethe–Slater curve where it is calculated as negative two times its namesake integral times two adjacent spins. That energy due to this phenomenon must be greater than one according to the Stoner criterion for ferromagnetism.
The exchange interaction is primarily due to electron repulsion and this rule which says that no two spins can be in the same quantum state.

answers: The Mabinogion [accept The Four Branches of the Mabinogi]
Wales [or Cymru; prompt on Britain, or United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or UK]
parts: Name this mythological woman, a reflection of the Celtic horse-goddess motif. By her husband Pwyll (“pwill”), she gave birth to the future king Pryderi (“prih-DARE-ee”).
Pwyll, Pryderi, and Rhiannon are characters in this text, though only Pryderi appears in all four of its branches. It was compiled and published by Lady Charlotte Guest.
The Mabinogion is a collection of tales from this country whose capital is Cardiff.

answers: Battle of Red Cliffs [or Battle of Chibi; or Chìbì zhī zhàn]
parts: Name this 208 A.D. battle in which Huang Gai utilized empty, burning ships to defeat his enemy.
The Battle of Red Cliffs was a defeat for Cao Cao during this period of Chinese history, which saw conflicts between the states of Wei, Shu, and Wu.

In this later Chinese naval battle, Zhang Hongfan’s burning ships failed to destroy Zhang Shijie’s chained fleet because the boats were covered with mud. Hongfan won the battle after playing music to cover a surprise attack.
The notes of the Aeolian mode form this scale. This type of scale begins on the sixth degree of a related key and is exemplified by playing only white keys from A to A on a piano.

This other mode starts on the mediant of its relative major scale. A piece that utilizes this mode is Bach’s Brandenburg Concerto No. 3, where a related cadence forms the entirety of its second movement.
Modes were frequently used to write these monophonic chants, which were typically sung unaccompanied in the Catholic Church and are named after a 6th-century pope.

answers: Raskolnikov's four dreams [prompt on dreams with “Whose dreams?”]
Crime and Punishment [or Prestupléniye i nakazániye]
Napoleon Bonaparte [the novel not mentioned is War and Peace by Leo Tolstoy]
parts: Identify these sequences. The last one of these sequences describes a plague of microbes that causes people to believe they are right and everyone else is wrong, representing a character’s belief that he is an “extraordinary man”.
The dreams of Raskolnikov appear in this novel about a murder of a pawnbroker, written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.

Raskolnikov’s belief that he is an “extraordinary man” leads him to frequently compare himself to this historical figure. In another novel, the injured officer Andrei Bolkonsky has a revelation while looking at the sky before he is saved by this man.
Name this ability that is the basis for counter-illumination camouflage in Hawaiian bobtail squid, from its symbiotic relationship with Aliivibrio fischeri.
Krill bioluminescence occurs through the luciferin in the dinoflagellate they eat, which contain a tetrapyrrole ring derived from this molecule. This green pigment is used for photosynthesis.

Some dinoflagellates resort to this phenomenon for photosynthesis. Sea slugs in the clade Sacoglossa can undergo this phenomenon in which certain organelles from algae are “stolen” to form a symbiotic relationship.

answers: High Holy Days [or High Holidays, or Yamim Noraim, or Days of Awe]
parts: Name this man whose murder by Yishmael ben Netaniah was commemorated by the rabbis, who instituted fast commemorating him on the third of Tishrei.
The Fast of Gedaliah is observed during this period in the Jewish liturgy, which begins with Rosh Hashanah and sees the celebration of several important ritual events.
The High Holy Days conclude with this day, on which the Kol Nidre prayer is recited and Jews fast from sundown to sundown. Its name means “Day of Atonement” in Hebrew.
Name this US Navy Commodore who was killed in an 1807 duel with James Barron.
Decatur had previously achieved fame for ordering the burning of the captured USS Philadelphia in this series of wars against North African pirates.
Barron challenged Decatur to a duel after Decatur criticized his behavior during this event, whose political fallout resulted in the Embargo Act of 1807.
Name this Poet Laureate who wrote a novel in which Judge Irwin commits suicide after being blackmailed by his son over a bribe.
This current Poet Laureate is the first Native American to hold the position. She describes “bodies of sand” and “maps drawn of blood” in her poem “She Had Some Horses.”
This African-American poet served as the last Consultant in Poetry, which was replaced by the Poet Laureate in 1986. This poet of “The Bean Eaters” also wrote the poem “We Real Cool.”
